data.author: Anmol Sharma
data.content: Serbian scientists named a new species of beetle after ex-world number one men's tennis player Novak Djokovic. The insect, which belongs to Duvalius genus of ground beetles present in Europe and was discovered several years ago in underground pit in Serbia, has been named 'Duvalius djokovici'. "We feel urged to pay Djokovic back in...way we can," a researcher said.
data.title: New species of beetle named after Novak Djokovic

data.author: Anmol Sharma
data.content: Air pollution particles have been found in developing lungs and brains of unborn babies for the first time, a study by University of Aberdeen and Hasselt University in Belgium stated. Thousands of black carbon particles were found in each cubic millimetre of tissue, which were breathed in by mother during pregnancy and then passed through bloodstream and placenta to foetus.
data.title: Toxic air pollution particles found in lungs, brains of unborn babies for the first time

data.author: Sakshita Khosla
data.content: NASA has shared a new picture of Jupiter's Europa moon, which is the smallest of the gas giant's four Galilean moons and also the sixth largest moon in our solar system. The picture was taken by NASA's Juno spacecraft on September 29, 2022. It revealed the "complex, ice-covered surface" of Europa as captured by Juno during its flyby.
data.title: NASA releases new pic of Jupiter's ice-covered moon Europa captured by Juno

data.author: Sakshita Khosla
data.content: Scientists from The University of Sydney have announced that a graveyard of ancient stars has been mapped in the Milky Way galaxy for the first time. The 'galactic underworld' stretches three times the height of the Milky Way, the researchers said. They have charted "the corpses of once massive suns that have since collapsed into black holes and neutron stars".
data.title: Scientists map 'graveyard of stars' in our galaxy for the 1st time, pics released

data.author: Hiral Goyal
data.content: NASA has released a picture of "fingerprint-like pattern" formed by two giant stars that come together about once every eight years. The image, captured by James Webb Space Telescope, shows at least 17 concentric dust rings. Each ring was created when the two stars came close together and their stellar winds met, compressing the gas and forming dust, NASA said.
data.title: NASA shares pic of dust 'fingerprint' created by 2 stars that meet once every 8 years

data.author: Anmol Sharma
data.content: As per a new study on a black hole that ripped a star in 2018, it's spewing out matter despite not swallowing anything in last few years. "No one has ever seen anything like this before," Yvette Cendes, the author of the study, said. It's spitting out material that's travelling at half the speed of light, the study added.
data.title: Material coming out of black hole is like nothing we've ever seen: Scientists

data.author: Pragya Swastik
data.content: Microplastics have been found in human breast milk for the first time, according to a research published in the peer-reviewed journal Polymers. An Italian team of researchers took breast milk samples from 34 healthy mothers a week after giving birth and microplastics were detected in 75% of them. The researchers found microplastics composed of polyethylene, PVC and polypropylene.
data.title: Microplastics found in human breast milk for the first time

data.author: Hiral Goyal
data.content: Scientists have confirmed that orcas hunt great white sharks, after drone and helicopter footage showed first evidence of a pod of orcas killing a great white near Mossel Bay in South Africa. The footage shows five killer whales chasing sharks in an hour-long pursuit, before killing one of them. Researchers believe that three other sharks may also have been killed.
data.title: Orcas caught chasing, killing great white shark on video for the first time

data.author: Daisy Mowke
data.content: NASA shared satellite images showing aerial view of US' Florida before and after the approach of "extremely dangerous" Hurricane Ian. "Turquoise colour is likely sediment that Ian lifted from...seafloor," said NASA. Prior to the storm, there was already some colour, but much of that is due to light reflecting off sea grass beds, seafloor and coral reefs, it added.
data.title: Pics show aerial view of US' Florida before and after Hurricane Ian's approach

data.author: Ankush Verma
data.content: The spacecraft which NASA deliberately crashed into an asteroid last month succeeded in nudging the rocky moonlet from its natural path into a faster orbit, marking the first time humanity has altered motion of a celestial body. The DART mission also represented world's first test of a planetary defense system designed to prevent a potential doomsday meteorite collision with Earth.
data.title: Asteroid's path altered after NASA deliberately crashes spacecraft into it

data.author: Aishwarya Awasthi
data.content: SpaceX launched 52 Starlink satellites seven hours after launching members of the Crew-5 mission to the space station on Wednesday. The satellites lifted off atop a Falcon 9 rocket from California's Vandenberg Space Force Base. They were deployed about 62 minutes after liftoff. SpaceX now plans to launch the Intelsat G-33/G-34 mission on October 6.
data.title: SpaceX launches 52 Starlink satellites hours after launching Crew-5 mission

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: Thirdhand smoke, which consists of dust particles from tobacco smoke that remain on surfaces, may trigger skin diseases. According to the study, acute exposure to these particles called THS elevates levels of molecules in the body linked to diseases like contact dermatitis and psoriasis. It may also lead to other diseases, such as cancer, heart disease, and atherosclerosis, researchers said.
data.title: Thirdhand smoke can trigger skin diseases: Study

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: The Draconid meteor shower is all set to light up the skies between 9 to 10 October. According to NASA, these meteors are generally faint owing to their relatively slow movement as they enter Earth's atmosphere at just 40,000 mph. Hence, researchers believe, this time, the meteor might appear even fainter due to the full moon rising on October 9.
data.title: Draconid meteor shower set to light up skies on October 9 &10

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: As per researchers, a new supercontinent will be created as the Pacific ocean is slowly closing up. It's shrinking by around one inch a year, due to which the tectonic plates on which the Americas rest are getting pushed westwards, they said. After 200-300 million years, the landmasses of Americas and Asia might collide to create a new supercontinent, Amasia.
data.title: New supercontinent 'Amasia' will be created as Pacific ocean shrinks: Study

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: Astronomers have discovered a pair of stars with an extremely short orbit that appear to circle each other every 51 minutes. The system could be a "cataclysmic variable," in which a sun-like star orbits tightly around a white dwarf, a hot, dense core of a burned-out star. In next 70 million years, their orbital period would reduce to 18 minutes.
data.title: 'Cataclysmic' pair of stars that orbit each other in less than an hour discovered

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: NASA's Dragonfly rotorcraft is scheduled to land on the Selk Crater region of Saturn's moon Titan in 2034. The region is a patchwork of sand dunes and broken-up ice. "Dragonfly will land in an equatorial, dry region of Titan, a frigid, thick-atmosphere, hydrocarbon world. It rains liquid methane sometimes, but it's more like a desert on Earth," a researcher said.
data.title: NASA’s Dragonfly to land on dunes & shattered ice on Saturn’s moon in 2034

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: Scientists believe broccoli gas could help provide compelling evidence of life on other planets. In order to expel toxins, broccoli, like other organisms, adds one carbon and three hydrogen atoms to an unwanted chemical and turns the potential toxin into a gas that floats away into atmosphere safely. Detection of such gases on other planets may hint at alien life.
data.title: Broccoli gas can help in finding life on other planets: Scientists

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: Archaeologists have unearthed eight centuries-old mummies in Peru. The ancient preserved corpses also included the remains of children. "This finding backs our hypothesis that this could be [a] cemetery from the colonial period," a researcher said. The mummies were found in unusual positions and with a mix of textiles that pointed to the influence of Spanish colonials, an official said.
data.title: 8 colonial-era mummies unearthed in Peru

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: ESA's Solar Orbiter took a sequence of images that show the sun blazing with solar explosions before making its last close approach to the Sun on Friday. The colours in the images were, however, added artificially because the original wavelength of the light emitted by the gas in the Sun's atmosphere is invisible to the human eye.
data.title: ESA spacecraft takes fiery visuals of Sun before close fly-by

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: According to a study, playing video games can trigger heart attacks in kids with underlying cardiac problems. Some kids are born with cardiac arrhythmia, an abnormal heartbeat, which remains untreated until a scan reveals it. The excitement, adrenaline, and emotional investment while playing video games can cause a flare-up leading to loss of consciousness, cardiac arrest, and even death.
data.title: Video games could trigger heart attack in kids with cardiac problems: Study

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: The primary function of the human brain's cerebellum is the regulation of movement. But scientists have recently discovered that the cerebellum also plays an important role in remembering emotional experiences. In the study that involved 1,418 participants, researchers found that the cerebellum showed an increase in brain activity of the participants while remembering positive and negative images.
data.title: Scientists discover new function of human brain's cerebellum

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: A fossil of a cat-sized reptile that was closely related to an extinct group of flying reptiles known as pterosaurs has been unearthed in Scotland. Named Scleromochlus taylori, the reptile lived on Earth about 240 to 210 million years ago. Scleromochlus had a large head, a long tail, a short neck, and a slender body, and stood on spindly legs.
data.title: Fossil of cat-sized reptile, an early relative of flying reptile, found in Scotland

data.author: Anisha Joneja
data.content: India's space economy is expected to be worth nearly $13 billion by 2025, according to a report released by the Indian Space Association (ISpA) and Ernst and Young. The satellite launch services segment will witness the highest growth due to government allowing participation of private players, the report added. In 2020, India's space economy was pegged at $9.6 billion.
data.title: Indian space economy to reach $13 bn by 2025: Report

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: China launched the Advanced Space-based Solar Observatory (ASO-S), nicknamed Kuafu-1, its first solar observatory on October 9. Kuafu-1 aims to unravel the mysteries of the Sun's eruptions. It will provide insights into how the Sun's magnetic field causes coronal mass ejections (CMEs) and other eruptions. It will also conduct simultaneous observations of both solar flares and CMEs.
data.title: 1st solar observatory to solve mystery of Sun’s eruptions launched by China

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: Scientists have said that reflections on the surface of Mars under its south pole could be caused by layers of ice and carbon dioxide and not by water. "On Earth, reflections that are bright are often an indication of liquid water, even buried lakes...But on Mars...it should be too cold for similar lakes to form," a researcher said.
data.title: Reflections from Mars not caused due to water: Scientists
